Psychological Trumpâ€™s behavior is not created by his illness; it is who he has always been. He is just becoming uncontrollable. By all standards except a formal diagnosis, Trump has always been a Dark Tetrad personality type: narcissistic, psychopathic, Machiavellian, and sadistic.

Similar symptoms may arise from mini-strokes. Perhaps when he disappeared for a week. Trump disclosed an MRI but â€œdidnâ€™t know what part of the bodyâ€ He denied it was his brain because they gave him another cognitive testâ€”his third. He is getting worse, and they cannot make him better.

Gullible Perhaps the most alarming symptom of dementia, whether FTD or Alzheimerâ€™s, is that it makes the patient far more suggestible, and vulnerable to malign influence. Scientifically, according to a 2025 study, dementia makes people more gullible. In a president, this is a deeply concerning.

Note that Trumpâ€™s family history is supportive of a dementia diagnosis. His father Fred suffered from dementia which Trump said was â€œprobablyâ€ Alzheimerâ€™sâ€”which is often a misdiagnosis for FTD. Several other members of his family have also suffered from dementia.

His ability to filter himselfâ€”even for his own goodâ€”is effectively gone. His internal regulatory system no longer functions at all, even for self-preservation. He is completely disinhibited. He now feels free to be as hateful as he feels insideâ€”regardless of the consequences.

Here are some of the most common behavioral changes in early FTD according to the Mayo Clinic: - Increasingly inappropriate social behavior. - Loss of empathy and skilled persuasion. - Lack of judgment - Loss of inhibition - Lack of interest, empathy Each of these has gotten substantially worse.

I believe there are two neurophysiological factors at play: serious vascular problems, and dementia, likely whatâ€™s called behavior-variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) the most common form of FTDâ€”which can symptomatically run its course over many years.

Neurophysiological There are numerous psychological pressures on Trump, but the neurological symptoms cannot be ignoredâ€”we note his obvious physical problems. Trump has had bruisingâ€”and now a full bandageâ€”on his hand for months. He effectively disappeared from view for a week, with no explanation.

The hepatitis B vaccine was introduced in 1981 There were 21,152 cases that year. Hepatitis B peaked at 27,000 in 1985. Vaccination brought that down to under 4,000 in 2013.

Parents have a choice to ask your neonatal MD to prescribe Hepatitis B Vaccine for your newborn, after the first 24 hours. The problem is your health insurance will not cover the cost of the shot. You will have to pay for that out of your pocket. You can thank Trump and RFK Jr.

Infants and young children are especially vulnerable: up to 90 percent of infants infected at birth develop chronic infection and 25 percent of infected children die prematurely from hepatitis-related disease. Irrational AntiVax conspiracy theorists at CDC will kill Americans if we don't stop them.
Before the United States adopted a recommendation for universal infant hepatitis B vaccination in 1991, thousands of children were infected each year â€” both at birth and during childhood.

Hepatitis B is a highly infectious virus that attacks the liver and can cause chronic liver disease, liver cancer, liver failure, and death. It spreads easily â€” by inconspicuous nonvisible blood or body fluids and can survive on surfaces for up to seven days.

The Vaccine Integrity Project found that the vaccine is safe regardless of when it is given, and there are no benefits to delaying the first dose. Delaying the first dose increases the risk of infection and jeopardizes completion of the full vaccine series - required for long-lasting protection.

The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices ended hepatitis B vaccination for all infants at birth. In spite of proven results. Delaying the birth dose of hepatitis B vaccine will lead to more children and adults developing preventable liver disease and liver cancer, with zero benefit.

West Coast Health Alliance, and Leading National Medical Organizations Recommend Hepatitis B Vaccination for Newborns Hepatitis B vaccinations for all infants at birth have reduced pediatric hepatitis B infections in the United States by 99 percent. RFK Jr ended them. doh.wa.gov/newsroom/wes...

The information was classified 'SECRET/NOFORN"", meaning it was classified Secret and precautions should not be leaked to foreign nationals. By using his personal cellphone, and by sharing Classified Secret mission plans with people without a need to know, Hegseth violated Military Law.

The 'Signal-gate' scandal led to bipartisan calls for Mr Hegseth's resignation, but it was Mike Waltz, who lost his job. It later emerged that Hegseth had created a second Signal group, including his wife, brother and personal lawyer, and shared much of the same detail there.

""We are clean on OPSEC"" - operational security, suggesting the sender understood the sensitivity of the information. But a journalist from The Atlantic had been added to the group chat and reported how the top-secret military operation had been shared both in advance and in real time.

The detail circulated in a group chat on the Signal app in March this year related to an imminent strike on Houthi rebels in Yemen. Messages reportedly posted by Mr Hegseth included: ""1415: Strike drones on target (THIS IS WHEN THE FIRST BOMBS WILL DEFINITELY DROP).""

Clinging to Past Status A narcissist may fixate on their former achievements, insisting they are still in control despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary. They may boast about wealth, influence, or imagined past successes long after these things have ceased to be relevant.

Final Stages: The Loss of Identity vs. Narcissistic Resistance As dementia reaches its final stages, a narcissistâ€™s ability to recognize themselves and others fades. However, their resistance to dependence and decline may persist.
Warped Memories That Serve Their Narrative A narcissist with dementia may misremember past events in ways that validate their self-image.

Extreme Dependence Coupled With Contempt Despite their past emphasis on independence and superiority, narcissists often become extremely dependent. This dependency, however, does not come with gratitude. Instead, they may belittle and criticize the very people who are providing their care.

Tantrum-Like Behavior Just as a child throws a tantrum when they don't get their way, an aging narcissist with dementia may scream, cry, or lash out when they feel ignored or powerless. This behavior can be exhausting for caregivers, who may struggle to balance compassion with self-preservation.

Regression to a More Primitive Narcissistic State As dementia strips away a narcissistâ€™s cognitive abilities, they often revert to a more primitive state of narcissism, where entitlement, rage, and neediness become more blatant.

Triangulation Efforts Deteriorate A hallmark of narcissistic manipulation is triangulationâ€”pitting people against each other to maintain control. As their cognitive function declines, their attempts at manipulation may become more obvious and less effective, leading to outbursts when they fail.

Fabrication and Deception Become Less Coherent Narcissists are skilled at weaving elaborate lies, but dementia makes it difficult to maintain consistency. Their stories may become nonsensical, contradictory, or childlike in nature, exposing their deceit in ways that were once less obvious.

The Decline of Manipulative Capabilities While a narcissist may still attempt to manipulate those around them, their cognitive impairment limits their ability to do so effectively. This shift can be disorienting for both the narcissist and their long-suffering victims. (Congress?)

Increased Emotional Volatility Mood swings are common in dementia patients, but in narcissists, these swings often manifest as exaggerated rage, sulking, or self-pity. Because they spent a lifetime avoiding responsibility, they may lash out rather than acknowledge their own distress.

Amplified Projection and Blame A narcissist with dementia may struggle to recall their own actions. They blame others for their forgetfulness, accuse loved ones of betraying them, and deny obvious lapses in memory. Their instinct to shift blame remains intact, even as they lose grip on reality.

Paranoia and Suspicion Intensify As dementia progresses, paranoia becomes a common. For narcissists, this tendency is magnified. They may believe their others are stealing from them, lying to them, or plotting against them. This belief often leads to false accusations and emotional outbursts.

SNAP is currently not paying out to Americans because President Donald Trump is defying multiple federal court rulings issued Friday, requiring him to tap a $6 billion contingency fund to ensure benefit payments go out.

But on Sunday, Catherine Rampell, a reporter at the Washington Post published an email from the USDA that was sent to grocery stores around the country, telling them they were prohibited from offering special discounts to those at greater risk of food insecurity due to the cuts.

Several grocery chains and food delivery apps have announced in recent days that they would provide substantial discounts to those whose Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits have been delayed. More than 1 in 8 Americans rely on the program, and 39% of them are children.

As the Trump administration continued its illegal freeze on food assistance, the US Department of Agriculture sent a warning to grocery stores not to provide discounts to the more than 42 million Americans affected.

First, they cut the state share of school financing. When State Government underpays formulas or piles on unfunded mandates, districts have two choices, raise local rates or cut classroom staff. Either way, homeowners pay.

In practice, itâ€™s a cost shift, from the state budget to you. They brag about keeping state taxes â€œlow,â€ then quietly shove school costs onto local property rolls and call it conservative. Itâ€™s Shell Game Government.

Republican officials and American CEOs and mega-investors have been opposed to workersâ€™ rights and power for a very long time. Today, the bough has been bent to the point that itâ€™s almost broken. A catastrophic snap may come soon.
For now, itâ€™s important to remember that the federal assault on workersâ€™ rights isnâ€™t all Trumpâ€™s doing, or Muskâ€™s, or Bezosâ€™s.
By granting that immediate injunction, it nullified Board attorneysâ€™ power to even investigate allegations.

But by going beyond that to flatly declare that the Board itself was unconstitutional, it completely blocked workers from any attempts to have the actâ€™s protection of their rights upheld by, or even heard by, federal courts in those three states.
The Fifth Circuit could have ruled that it was the actâ€™s language forbidding presidents to make at-will firings that was unconstitutional.

The agency is now inert at the top, and has an acting general counsel put there by Trump. Trumpâ€™s nominee for permanent general counsel, Crystal Carey, a former partner at Morgan Lewis, the firm representing SpaceX, declined to say she believed the NLRB was constitutional in her Senate confirmation.

Both Musk and his fellow worldâ€™s-richest-human competitor, Jeff Bezos, had initiated suits last year claiming that the actâ€”the only act that gives workers the power to bargain with their employers and seek remedies when those employers violate labor lawsâ€”was unconstitutional.

The two Trump-appointed judges and the one George H.W. Bushâ€“appointed judge who heard the case found for SpaceX, in a ruling that will now extend to any and every case before the NLRB adjudicated in the Fifth Circuit, which encompasses Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas.

(See, e.g., Muskâ€™s effect on Tesla sales.) The union-busting firm of Morgan Lewis, based their claim on the argument that the Board itself was unconstitutional, since it had been established, and had been operating for the past 90 years, as an agency that the president couldnâ€™t completely control.

SpaceX sought an immediate injunction overturning the Boardâ€™s right to investigate those charges, saying that it inflicted â€œirreparable harmâ€ on the company, even though it was the fired workers who suffered harm and the only entity inflicting irreparable harm on Muskâ€™s companies was Musk himself.

Last week, the Fifth Circuit circumscribed the NLRB even more. Muskâ€™s SpaceX filed against the Board, in a pending NLRB investigation into claims that SpaceX had violated its workersâ€™ rights by firing eight for posting that Muskâ€™s verbal outbursts and ranting were hurting the company.

By upholding Trumpâ€™s firing of Wilcox and other heads of regulatory agencies, those justices have positioned themselves to rule that such limitations violate the Constitutionâ€™s vesting of executive power in the president.
The Republican justices are expected to soon reverse the Courtâ€™s 1935 ruling in a case called Humphreyâ€™s Executor, which limited the presidentâ€™s power over independent regulatory agencies.

The novel unitary executive theory holds that federal agencies established by Congress and signed into law to be independent of presidential power, save only the power to appoint their leaders, are now in violation of the newly discovered right of presidents to completely control these agencies.

Under the law, presidents had the power to remove members before their terms expire only in the event of â€œneglect of duty or malfeasance in office,â€ which Trump didnâ€™t even allege when he fired Wilcox. In May, the Supreme Court upheld the novel unitary executive power to fire Board members at will.

The Board is only down to two members because President Trump fired Biden-appointed and congressionally confirmed Board chair Gwynne Wilcox in the middle of her term, which, as for all Board members, was set by the NLRA to run for five years.

This enables employers whoâ€™ve been found to have violated workersâ€™ rights by lower NLRB administrative courts to appeal those findings and penalties to the Board, which cannot rule on anythingâ€”essentially, giving those employers leeway to keep on doing what theyâ€™re doing, however illegal it may be.
Currently, the fact that the five-member National Labor Relations Board is down to just two membersâ€”not enough to constitute a quorumâ€”means the Board can make no rulings.

Until last week, when the avowedly far-right Fifth Circuit decided otherwise. Today, the NLRA hovers somewhere between de facto and de jure nullification. Itâ€™s been slowly eroding for 50 years, as employer resistance to it has heightened, and as the penalties to employers have weakened.

The National Labor Relations Actâ€”that pillar of American democracy that gives workers the right to bargain collectively with their employersâ€”was enacted 90 years ago. Its constitutionality was upheld two years later by the Supreme Court. No challenge to its constitutionality has succeeded since.

Republicans in Texas have fought tooth and nail to ban a state income tax (which would hit wealthy earners hardest) and instead rely on sales and property taxes (which eat up a far bigger share of a working familyâ€™s paycheck). That structure shifts the tax burden down the ladder:
Texas is one of the most regressive tax systems in the country. That means that low and middle-income households pay a larger share of their income in state/local taxes than the top 1%.
